messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:50): cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:50): i'm playing twilight imperium 3 right now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:50): but when i get back home i'll send mail about it
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:51): waits for recompile

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:53): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: it's not so much the timing of the late-breaking changes that makes me sad as that they're going to make it very, very, very hard for anything like the original circumstances where postMessage got approval to land so late to ever happen again
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:53): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: I think if people had known the two sets of changes were going to happen after that, they'd have said no
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:53): heck, *I* might even have said no

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:54): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: I probably would have said yes to the postMessage work before Safari 3.1 even if I had known it would be followed by changes, because I think that level of engagement was part of what led to the changes
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:54): (and I think the changes that made us pull it were for the better)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:55): I do understand that implementing features against an unstable spec, especially late in a dev cycle, can be disruptive
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:55): I had the work all done for several months; it just wasn't in the tree because we were "past" feature freeze
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:55): I don't mind the implementation
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:55): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: If the feature wasn't approved for FF3, how long would it be before it could be in a release?
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:55): that's the other half of the matter
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:55): as I understand it .next is supposed to be a quick turnaround, but I don't know how quick
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:56): Is .next different from Mozilla 2?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:56): Mozilla 2 has never sounded particularly likely for quick turnaround to me
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:56): a 3.5, so to speak, with a few cherry-picked things
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:56): for Safari/WebKit I am expecting gaps of less than a year between releases with new engine features for the foreseeable future
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:56): The whole "let's (automatically) rewrite all our code and change all our APIs" thing makes me a little nervous
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:56): if it's not different from 2, then it's not a quick turnaround
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:57): the change APIs thing is more, "we'll change where we've needed to change"
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (02:57): Mozilla 2 work is being scoped back beyond the vague "rewrite everything" plans from 2 years ago
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:57): wonders if he might get canvas shadows into 3.5 :-)
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:57): but yeah, I'm still not clear on exactly how everything's panning out
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (02:57): and, that's expected, really
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (02:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: almost certainly
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:58): reasonably self-contained feature-size things are generally what's in the plans
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:58): Hmm, I did the shadow thing six months ago - I didn't realise it was that long :-/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:59): (and apparently it was feature freeze back then)
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:59): so the 100K patch that adds stuff and doesn't have twisty interactions but is just too late to trust, is the prototypical "take"
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:59): but no fundamental reworkings of anything
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:59): That sounds quite sensible
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:22): Hooray, I used the scientific method today

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:23): There were about a hundred small flying insects sitting on the ceiling by the light above my bed this evening, so I hypothesised that they were attracted by lights

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:24): so I turned that light off and pointed a desk lamp at a wall as far away as possible (about two metres) from my bed, and after several hours they've nearly all migrated to that wall
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:24): so I think I'll consider my hypothesis to be true
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:24): Also it means I can go to bed without being scared of insects dropping onto my head
fe70b49783daa65bcb249805fb3a2b24 (03:25): you can consider your hypothesis not falsified by your experiment
fe70b49783daa65bcb249805fb3a2b24 (03:25): (if you wanna be hardcore scientific method)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:25): I don't want to be that hardcore - I like to be able to believe that at least some things in this world are true, and aren't merely not known to be false :-)
